metadata.case_name: Dr. Jiwan Lal & Ors. v. Brij Mohan Mehra

facts.text: Agreement dated December 9, 1959 between Dr. Jiwan Lal (first appellant), Shri Krishan Das (second appellant), Bal Kishan Das (predecessor of appellants Nos. 3 to 8), and Brij Mohan Mehra for sale of premises for Rs. 1,22,500/- with Rs. 10,000/- paid as earnest money.

Material terms in clauses 5, 6, 7 and 9: Sale deed to be executed within three months after premises vacated by Income-tax Authorities and intimation given; on requisition prior to registration, vendor to refund Rs. 10,000/- plus 6% interest; if purchasers fail to complete, earnest money forfeited; vendor to effect repairs post-vacation at purchasers' expense; purchasers to pay chowkidar expenses.
Premises requisitioned by Additional District Magistrate, Amritsar on January 23, 1960.
Brij Mohan Mehra refused to execute sale deed despite requests by prospective vendees.
Plaintiffs instituted suit for specific performance on November 5, 1962.
Subordinate Judge, 1st Class, Amritsar decreed suit on August 17, 1964, finding plaintiffs ready and willing, agreement not void, no manipulation needed to decide, waiver of cl.6, no laches.

Punjab High Court reversed decree on January 25, 1966 in Civil Regular First Appeal No. 362 of 1964, holding cl.6 imposed obligations only if vacant possession, contract fell through on requisition, no waiver.
Brij Mohan Mehra sent letter with cheque for Rs. 10,103.28 on February 11, 1960, interest calculated from December 9, 1959.
Brij Mohan Mehra appealed requisition order, dismissed on August 1, 1960.

Correspondence between parties Feb 11 to April 27, 1960; vendees repeatedly asked for sale deed, stated readiness; notice on April 17, 1960 to appear April 30 (holiday), telegram sent, Rs.1,12,500 tendered, Brij Mohan absent.
Post-April 1960, Dr. Jiwan Lal continued pressing Brij Mohan to execute sale deed, denied abandonment.
Property prices depreciated from October 1962 due to Chinese aggression.

legal_issues.text: Was the non-requisitioning of the premises a condition precedent to the performance of the seller's obligation to sell?
Was the non-requisitioning of the premises a condition precedent to the performance of the buyers' obligation to buy?
Could the buyers waive the condition and insist on the performance of the seller's obligation?
Were the buyers guilty of laches and was there abandonment of their claim?

petitioner_arguments.text: Premises requisitioned on manipulation of Brij Mohan Mehra.
Clause 6 intended for benefit of prospective vendees.
Prospective vendees waived condition in cl.6.
Brij Mohan could not put an end to contract by relying on cl.6.
Plaintiffs always ready and willing to perform.
Not guilty of laches or abandonment.

respondent_arguments.text: Agreement was contingent, became void on requisitioning.
No contract existed prior to requisition.
Plaintiffs could not waive condition in cl.6.
Guilty of laches and abandoned rights.

court_reasoning.text: There was a concluded contract from inception; cl.1 vendor agreed to sell, purchasers to buy; cl.5 liability to execute within time.

Cl.6 does not expressly subject seller's obligation to non-requisitioning; no clear language to end contract; seller businessman unlikely to disadvantage self; object of vendees for vacant possession, not seller; no repair provision post-requisition; interest from agreement date per conduct.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Non-requisitioning not condition precedent for seller.

court_reasoning.text: Cl.6 for vendees' benefit (wanted vacant for hotel); implies right to rescind and demand refund.
Cl.6 for exclusive benefit of vendees, so waivable unilaterally; cites Dalsukh Pancholi (PC held non-exclusive can't waive), Hawksley, Morrell.

No laches: waited reasonably till appeal dismissal Aug 1, 1960; suit within 2 yrs 3 mths 4 days; correspondence shows insistence; tendered money April 1960; continued pressing; no prejudice to seller (prices fell post-suit); cites Lindsay Petroleum on laches not arbitrary.

holdings.text: Non-requisitioning not condition precedent to seller's obligation to sell.
Non-requisitioning was condition precedent to buyers' obligation to buy.
Buyers not guilty of laches or abandonment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dalsukh M. Pancholi v. The Guarantee Life and Employment Insurance Co., Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Condition for exclusive benefit of one party can be waived unilaterally.
Supports waiver of condition for exclusive benefit.
Supports waiver of condition for exclusive benefit.
Doctrine of laches not arbitrary; considers prejudice and conduct.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court set aside High Court judgment and decree, restored Subordinate Judge's decree, directed Brij Mohan Mehra to execute sale deed on tender of Rs.1,12,500/- and expenses within two months; if fails, plaintiffs deposit in court within three months for execution.
outcome.relief_granted: Specific performance of agreement dated December 9, 1959.

key_quotes.text: "The doctrine of laches in courts of equity is not an arbitrary or technical doctrine."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains test for laches, quoting Lord Selborne.

key_quotes.text: "Clause 6 was inserted in the agreement for the exclusive benefit of the vendees and not for the benefit of the vendor as well as the vendees. So the vendees could waive the condition precedent specified in cl. 6."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on waivability of condition.

key_quotes.text: "There was a concluded contract between the parties. The seller became liable to sell and the buyer became liable to buy from the very inception of the contract."
key_quotes.speaker: court
